bestBHT.bht: When a fellow Christian errs, our role is to gently admonish, recognizing their belonging to the family of Christ. Rather than treating them as an adversary, we must approach with love and kindness, aiming for their repentance and restoration. Excommunication should not push them away; rather, it should serve as a means to bring them back when they have strayed. We are not to view them as enemies or deal with them harshly, but instead, we should offer compassionate admonition as brothers and sisters in Christ.

Henry Alford: And I know that it will follow as a consequence of your being Christians, that ye will, &c.
'And I know that it will follow as a consequence of your being Christians.'
'And I know that it will follow as a consequence of your being Christians, that ye will, &c.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: yet excommunicated (compare :-). Do not shun him in contemptuous silence, but tell him why
Albert Barnes: We are not to deal with a man as an adversary over whom we are to seek to gain a victory, but as an erring brother - a brother still, though he errs.
There is great danger that when we undertake the work of discipline we shall forget that he who is the subject of it is a brother, and that we shall regard and treat him as an enemy.
All is kind, and gentle, though firm; the offender is a man and a brother still; he is to be followed with tender sympathy and prayer.
Marvin Vincent: Admonish [νουθετειτε] . See on Acts 20:31, and Ephesians 6:4.
John Calvin: In short, excommunication does not tend to drive men from the Lord’s flock, but rather to bring them back when wandering and going astray.

We must observe, however, by what sign he would have brotherly love shewn — not by allurements or flattery, but by admonitions; for in this way it will be, that all that will not be incurable will feel that concern is felt for their welfare.

In the mean time, excommunication is distinguished from anathema: for as to those that the Church marks out by the severity of its censure, Paul admonishes that they should not be utterly cast away, as if they were cut off from all hope of salvation; but endeavors must be used, that they may be brought back to a sound mind.
Philip Schaff: Count him not as an enemy.
He was not to be counted hopeless.
This discipline was to be expected to terminate in his repentance and reclamation.
Archibald T. Robertson: Few things in our churches are more difficult of wise execution than the discipline of erring members.
This is always the problem in such ostracism as discipline, however necessary it is at times.
The word εχθρος is an adjective, hateful, from εχθος, hate.
John Gill: Yet count him not as an enemy... nor deal with him in a hostile, fierce, furious, and passionate manner, as if you were seeking his destruction, and not his restoration.
But admonish, or 'reprove' him as a brother;... with a brotherly affection, meekness, compassion, and tenderness.

The conduct of the church... should inquire, and diligently observe, what effect the ordinance of excommunication has upon them, and renew their admonitions and friendly reproofs, if possible, to recover them.
John Wesley: Admonish him as a brother — Tell him lovingly of the reason why you shun him.

bhtAttempts.bht: As Christians, it is our responsibility to admonish fellow believers who have gone astray, treating them not as adversaries to be defeated, but as erring brothers who still belong to the family of Christ. We must approach them with gentleness, firmness, and the hope of their repentance and reclamation in mind. Excommunication should not be seen as a means of driving them away, but rather as a way to draw them back when they have gone astray. We should not count them as enemies or deal with them in a hostile manner, but instead, we are to lovingly and compassionately admonish them, showing that we genuinely care for their spiritual well-being. The goal is not destruction, but restoration through brotherly affection and tenderness.

As Christians, when we encounter a fellow believer who has gone astray, we must remember that they are still part of our spiritual family. Instead of treating them as adversaries to be defeated, we are called to admonish them with kindness and love, seeking their repentance and reclamation. Excommunication should not be a means of driving them away, but rather a way to bring them back when they have wandered. We must approach the situation with tenderness, compassion, and the desire to restore them as our brothers and sisters in Christ.
